Sec. 42-37. - Specications. All street and sidewalk pavements and all curbing shall be laid in conformity with the specifications established or approved from time to time by the mayor and council. The standard for construction of curbs on each side of any town street, or any connecting street or road for which curbs have been prescribed, shall be not less than one amp per lineal block giving on the crosswalks at intersections. Ramps shall be at least 40 inches wide and so constructed as to allow reasonable access to the crosswalk for persons with physical disabilities. Sec. 42-38. - Barricades. Any person laying or repairing any pavement on a street, sidewalk, or other public place shall maintain suitable barricades to prevent injury to any person or vehicle by reason of the work, which barricades shall be protected by a light at nighttime. Secs. 42-39—42-59. - Reserved. Subdivision II. - Sidewalks 6/1/2019 Mount Airy, GA Code of Ordinances 238/316 (a) (b) (c) (d) (1) (2) (3) (4) Sec. 42-60. - Determination of need for sidewalk; construction; costs. Whenever the necessity for a sidewalk arises in any portion of the town, the street committee shall make a survey to determine the size, style, length, and manner of building the desired sidewalk. They shall then give all abutting property owners notice of the style of sidewalk to be built by them along, by and in front of their property. Within ten days after said notice shall be given, these said property owners shall construct and build, in accordance with the notice of said street committee, a sidewalk along, by and adjacent to their property at their own expense. Whenever the property owner is a nonresident the notice shall be served upon the tenant in possession, if there is one; if not, upon the agent of said person if his address is known; if unknown, said notice shall be posted as provided for posting of notices of tax sales on personal property. If said property owner fails or refuses to construct said sidewalks after notice, the street committee may order the police chief to construct same at the property owner's expense. The police chief shall proceed to so construct said sidewalk and keep an itemized account of the cost of same which he shall deliver to the clerk of the council. The clerk shall present a copy of said bill of cost to said property owner and demand payment of same. If the owner fails or refuses payment of same in 30 days, then the mayor shall issue a fi. fa. against said person and the property adjacent to said sidewalk, and put said fi. fa. in the hands of the police chief for collection. The police chief, when he receives such fi. fa., shall proceed to collect same by levy and sale of said property, and such levy and sale and all subsequent proceedings shall be similar to those provided for in the collection of taxes. (Code 1947, § 4-79) Secs. 42-61—42-83. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - PERMIT PROCEDURE Sec. 42-84. - Fees; bonds. Each applicant for a permit under this chapter shall be accompanied by a permit fee in the amount established in the town fee schedule and, in the discretion of the mayor and town council, a surety bond in an amount sufficient to indemnify the town for any loss or damage caused by or resulting from the work undertaken pursuant to the permit. Upon the disapproval of any application for which a fee has been submitted under the provisions of this chapter, the town clerk shall refund such fee, provided that the applicant is not otherwise indebted to the town. Sec. 42-85. - Standards for issuance of permit. The town clerk shall issue a permit hereunder when he finds: That the plans for the proposed operation have been approved by the street superintendent, to whom such plans shall be forwarded by the town clerk within a reasonable time after receipt thereof; That the work shall be done according to the standard specifications of the town for public work of like character; That the operation will not unreasonably interfere with vehicular and pedestrian traffic and the means of ingress to and egress from the affected and adjacent properties; and That the health, welfare, and safety of the public will not be unreasonably impaired. Sec. 42-86. - Supervision. 6/1/2019 Mount Airy, GA Code of Ordinances 239/316 (1) (2) (3) (4) (5) All work for which a permit is granted hereunder shall be under the direction and supervision of the street superintendent. Sec. 42-87. - Application for the issuance of permits. Every person required to procure a permit under the provisions of this chapter or any ordinance or law of this town relating to the subject matter of this chapter shall submit a written application for such permit to the town clerk. The written application shall state the following: The name and address of the applicant. The purpose for which the application is submitted. The nature and location of any work proposed to be done and the name of the person who is to do such work. The estimated cost of the proposed work. The date of commencement and date of completion of the proposed work, and other dates or plans as may reasonably be required by the town clerk or the street superintendent. Sec. 42-88. - Review of application. Upon receipt of the application for a permit under the provisions of this article, the town clerk shall forward such application to the street superintendent, who shall approve or disapprove such application within seven days after receipt thereof. After indicating approval or disapproval on the application, the street superintendent shall return the same to the town clerk. Sec. 42-89. - Issuance of permit. Upon receipt of an approved application from the street superintendent, the town clerk shall issue a permit to the applicant therefor, which permit shall state the nature of the work to be done or activity to be carried out and bear the date of issuance and the signature of the town clerk. Sec. 42-90. - Display of permit. It shall be the duty of any permittee hereunder to keep the permit issued to him in a conspicuous place at the site of the work or activity to be engaged in. It shall be unlawful for any person to exhibit such permit at or about any location not covered thereby, or to misrepresent the number of the permit or the date of expiration of the permit. Sec. 42-91. - Limitation of issuance. Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, no permit shall be issued to any applicant therefor who has failed to satisfy any bonding requirements imposed upon persons engaged in the kind of work or activity proposed to be done or carried out by such applicant. Secs. 42-92—42-107. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - STREET AND SIDEWALK MAINTENANCE Sec. 42-108. - Sidewalk maintenance. It shall be the duty of the town to keep walkways in good repair at all times and to remove from them all snow or ice whenever feasible. 6/1/2019 Mount Airy, GA Code of Ordinances 240/316 (a) (b) (a) (b) (c) (d) Sec. 42-109. - Maintenance of property between street and curbline. All persons who own real estate in the town which abuts upon any sidewalk which is paved shall be required to keep that portion of such sidewalk which lies between the property line and the curbline of the adjoining street, and upon which his real estate abuts, in good and smooth condition and free from growing weeds and other obnoxious and unsightly vegetation or other things which would mar or detract from the beauty and cleanliness of the street upon which their property abuts. Any property owner who shall place or allow grass to grow upon the portion of sidewalk lying between the property line and the curbline of the street as aforesaid, and upon which his real estate abuts, shall keep such grass properly mowed and free from rubbish of all kinds. If such owners are not in the possession of their property, then this section shall apply to their tenants or those who have possession or control of the same. Sec. 42-110. - Reports of defects and obstructions. It shall be the duty of every town officer and employee who becomes aware of any defect or obstruction, or of any unlawful deposit or discharge, in or on any public street, alley, curb, sidewalk, or other public way of the town to report the same to the street superintendent as soon as possible. Sec. 42-111. - Encroachments. It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or maintain any building or structure which encroaches upon any public street or property, or to erect any poles or wires or to maintain any poles or wires over any public place, street, alley, or other public way, without having first secured a permit from the town clerk in the manner specified in this chapter. Sec. 42-112. - Openings. It shall be unlawful for any person to construct or maintain any opening or stairway in any public street, sidewalk, or alley without first obtaining a permit from the town clerk in the manner specified in this article. All such lawfully maintained openings shall be guarded by a suitable strong cover or railing approved by the street superintendent. Sec. 42-113. - Trees and shrubs. It shall be unlawful for any person to plant, remove, injure, or cut any tree, bush, or shrub in or from any public street, parkway, or other public place without first obtaining a permit from the town clerk in the manner specified in this chapter. It shall be unlawful for any person to attach any sign, advertisement, or notice to any tree or shrub in any public place. Any tree or shrub which overhangs any sidewalk, street, or other public place in the town in such a way as to impede or interfere with traffic or travel shall be trimmed by the owner of the premises on which such tree or shrub grows so that the obstruction shall cease. Any tree or limb of a tree which is likely to fall on or across any public way or place shall be removed by the owner of the premises on which such tree grows or stands. The director of public works may cause to be trimmed or removed any and all such trees or shrubs so that the obstruction or danger of traffic or passage shall be removed. Sec. 42-114. - Poles and wires. Any person or company which maintains poles and wires in the streets, alleys, or other public places of the town shall keep such wires and poles free and away from any nearby trees or shrubs in such places, and keep all such trees and shrubs properly trimmed, subject to the supervision of the director of public works, so that no injury shall befall either the poles and wires or the 6/1/2019 Mount Airy, GA Code of Ordinances 241/316 (a) (b) (c) (d) (a) (b) shrubs and trees by their contact. Secs. 42-115—42-137. - Reserved. DIVISION 5. - PROHIBITED ACTS Sec. 42-138. - Defacing streets, sidewalks, and curbs. It shall be unlawful for any person to deface any public sidewalk, street, or curb in the town by painting any signs thereon, whether for commercial advertising purposes or not, or to walk or drive any vehicle upon or injure in any way any newly laid street, sidewalk, or curbing pavement while the same is guarded by a warning sign or barricade or is soft or newly laid. Sec. 42-139. - Obstructions. It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, create, or maintain any obstruction on any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public way, except as may be provided in this chapter or in the ordinances and laws of the town. It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct a sidewalk within the town by placement of any object, including, but not limited to, vending machines, items for sale, decorative items, or similar items on or above a sidewalk, unless a permit allowing the placement has been approved by the town. Applications for a permit shall be made to the town manager's office. In the event the application is denied by the town manager, the applicant may appeal this decision to the town council. Upon the report of a violation, the owner of the property shall be given a written notice, by certified mail to either remove the item or obtain a permit within five days of the date of their receipt of the notice. Failure to comply shall be considered a violation of this section. Notwithstanding the provisions herein, the town reserves the right to remove any items that present an immediate danger to public safety without prior notification. After notice has been served as described herein, and the five-day compliance period has elapsed, the town may remove the non-permitted item, and the owner shall be responsible for the cost of removal and storage. Items unclaimed after 30 days shall be considered abandoned property. Sec. 42-140. - Deposits and discharges. It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit on any street or sidewalk any rubbish or any material that may be harmful to the pavement thereof, or any waste material, or any glass or other article that may do injury to any person, animal, or property. It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge or to allow to be discharged onto any public street or sidewalk any water or other fluid material containing objectionable material such as sewage, waste milk, or other organic material. Thus, it shall be unlawful for anyone to wash autos on the town sidewalks. Sec. 42-141. - Private use. It shall be unlawful for any person to use any street, sidewalk, or other public place as space for the display of goods or merchandise for sale, or to write or make any sign or advertisement on any such pavement. Sec. 42-142. - Burning leaves and rubbish. It shall be unlawful for any person to burn any leaves, paper, rubbish, or other substances upon any of the public streets, sidewalks, or alleys of the town. 6/1/2019 Mount Airy, GA Code of Ordinances 242/316 (a) (b) Secs. 42-143—42-167. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - PARADES AND PUBLIC DEMONSTRATIONS Sec. 42-168. - Permit required. It shall be unlawful to organize or hold, or to assist in organizing or holding, or to take part or to participate in any parade or procession or other public demonstration on the streets or other public ways of the town, unless a permit therefor has been secured from the chief of police as is hereinafter provided. The permit fee shall be the amount set forth in the town fee schedule. Sec. 42-169. - Application. To secure such permit, a written application shall be made at least seven days prior to the proposed parade, procession, rally, or public demonstration to the chief of police. Said application must set forth the time, place, and manner in which such parade, procession, rally or public demonstration is to be conducted. Sec. 42-170. - Issuance of permit. The chief of police, after he has reviewed said application, shall grant a written permit for such parade, procession, rally, or public demonstration specifying the time said parade, procession, rally, or public demonstration shall take place; and designating the place, streets, or other public ways which may be used therefor; and specifying the manner in which said parade, procession, rally, or public demonstration shall be executed. In specifying the time, place and manner in which said parade, procession, rally, or public demonstration shall be executed, the chief of police shall take into consideration competing demands for public use of the streets, highways and parks so that their use by any permit applicant shall not unduly disturb such public use, or cause any danger or public disturbance. Sec. 42-171. - Street use restricted to permit. It shall be unlawful to use for such purposes any other streets, or public ways than those set out in said permit. Sec. 42-172. - Funeral processions excepted. This article is not intended to nor shall it apply to funeral processions.

div.head: Chapter 44 - TAXATION
div.p: (RESERVED)

div.head: Chapter 46 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): State Law reference— Motor vehicles and traffic, O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 et seq.; uniform rules of the road, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq.; off road vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-7-1 et seq.; equipment and inspection of motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-1 et seq.; abandoned motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-1 et seq.; use of speed detection devices, O.C.G.A. § 40-14-2 et seq.; cities and counties authorized to enact ordinances for removal of vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-4. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL (35) 6/1/2019 Mount Airy, GA Code of Ordinances 243/316 (a) (b) (c) (d) (1) (2) (3) (e) Secs. 46-1—46-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT Sec. 46-19. - Trac control devices. The public works department shall place and maintain traffic control signs, signals, and devices when and as required under the traffic ordinances of this town to make effective the provisions of such ordinances, and may place and maintain such additional traffic control devices as may be deemed necessary to regulate traffic under the traffic ordinances of this town or under state law. The public works department is authorized to place markers, buttons, turn lines or signs within or adjacent to intersections indicating the course to be traveled by vehicles turning at such intersections. The public works department is hereby authorized to determine those intersections at which drivers of vehicles shall not make a right or left turn and shall place proper signs at such intersections. The public works department is hereby authorized to take the following action: Designate and maintain, by appropriate devices, marks, or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections where in its opinion there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway, and at such other places as may be deemed necessary; Establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such places as may be deemed necessary for the protection of pedestrians; Mark lanes for traffic and spaces for parking and loading on street pavements at such places as may be deemed advisable, consistent with the traffic ordinances of this town. The public works department shall determine upon what streets angle parking shall be permitted and shall mark or sign such street accordingly. State law reference— Authority to regulate traffic by means of official traffic control devices preserved, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(2); traffic signs, signals, etc., O.C.G.A. § 40-6-20 et seq. Sec. 46-20. - Authority of police and re department ocials to enforce chapter. It shall be the duty of the officers of the police department and such officers as are assigned by the chief of police to such duty to enforce all traffic laws of this town. In addition, officers of the fire department when at the scene of a fire may direct or assist the police in directing traffic thereat or in the immediate vicinity. State law reference— Authority to regulate traffic by means of police officers preserved, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(1); obedience to persons directing traffic required, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-2. Sec. 46-21. - Records of trac violations. The police department shall keep a record of all violations of the traffic ordinances of this town with which any person has been charged, together with a record of the final disposition of all such alleged offenses. All such records and reports shall be public records. Sec. 46-22. - Trac accidents. 6/1/2019 Mount Airy, GA Code of Ordinances 244/316 (a) (b) (a) (1) (2) (3) (4) (5) (6) (7) (8) It shall be the duty of the officers of the police department to investigate traffic accidents, to arrest and to assist in the prosecution of those persons charged with violations of law causing or contributing to such accidents, and to file and maintain records containing such accident reports. State law reference— Accidents and accident reports, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-270 et seq. Sec. 46-23. - Issuance of summons. Any police officer upon making an arrest for violation of this chapter shall issue a summons to the alleged offender, directing him to appear at the next session of the municipal court, as the case may be, to answer the charges against him, requiring such bond as the police department may from time to time specify, but sufficient to ensure the appearance in court of alleged offender. Service of a summons upon an alleged parking offender by affixing same to the illegally parked vehicle shall be legal and sufficient service upon the alleged offender requiring him to appear in court as directed. Sec. 46-24. - Impoundment and disposition of motor vehicles. Any person, at the direction of the chief of police or a duly certified police officer, is hereby authorized to remove, or have removed at their direction, a vehicle from any public or private way or place, under any of the circumstances hereinafter enumerated, the council hereby finding and determining such vehicles under such circumstances to be obstructions to traffic or public nuisances. Such vehicle is authorized to be removed under any of the following circumstances: When any vehicle is left unattended upon any bridge, viaduct, subway or tunnel, or where such vehicle constitutes an obstruction to traffic; When a vehicle upon a public way is so disabled as to constitute an obstruction to traffic and the person in charge of the vehicle is by reason of physical injury incapacitated to such an extent as to be unable to provide for its custody or removal; When any vehicle is left unattended upon a street or parked illegally so as to constitute a definite hazard or obstruction to the normal movement of traffic, or left unattended on any public street with engine running or with keys in the ignition switch or locked; When any vehicle is parked or left standing upon any area or portion of a public street in violation of or contrary to a parking limitation or prohibition established by the chief of police, provided such area or portion of such public street has been posted with an official sign giving notice both of such limitation or prohibition and of the fact that such area or portion of such street is a tow-away area; When a vehicle is parked in violation of any traffic ordinance and is an obstruction or hazard or potential obstruction or hazard to any lawful function or limits the normal access to a use of any public or private property. When the driver of such vehicle is taken into custody by the police department and the vehicle would thereby be left unattended upon a street, highway or restricted parking area, or other public way. When the driver of a vehicle is reasonably suspected of using license plates or license permits unlawfully, misusing a license plate or license permit issued to the driver, or a vehicle is parked without proper license plates or license permits, or with no license plates or license permit, or driven or parked with an invalid or expired license permit; When the driver of a vehicle is driving without an operator's license or chauffeur's license which is current and valid, or who does not have such license in the driver's immediate possession, or who drives a vehicle contrary to restrictions imposed upon the license, or who drives a vehicle while their operator's or chauffeur's license 6/1/2019 Mount Airy, GA Code of Ordinances 245/316 (9) (10) (11) (12) (13) (14) (15) (b) (a) has been denied, suspended, cancelled or revoked by the state; When a vehicle is found parked on or so near to any railroad track as to block the same in any manner; When any truck-tractor is found to be parked in any metered parking space; When any semi-trailer is found to be parked in any metered parking space; When the driver of any vehicle, or the vehicle which the driver is driving, is reasonably suspected of having been involved in any hit-and-run accident; When any vehicle is reasonably suspected of being a stolen vehicle, or parts thereof to be stolen parts; When the driver of any vehicle is taken into custody for suspected felony or misdemeanor, or when the vehicle is suspected of containing stolen goods, or other contraband; When any vehicle is parked or stopped in an emergency access lane in violation of or contrary to a parking limitation or prohibition established by town ordinance, provided that such emergency access lane has been posted with an authorized sign giving notice both of such limitation or prohibition and of the fact that such area or portion of such public roadway or private property is a tow-away area. The owner of any vehicle so removed and impounded shall be required to pay storage and other costs incurred by virtue of such removal and impounding, regardless of the cause of the conduct necessitating such action by the police department. State law reference— Disposition of personal property in the custody of law enforcement agencies, O.C.G.A. § 17-5-4; authority to remove vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-3. Secs. 46-25—46-51. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - TRAFFIC REGULATIONS Sec. 46-52. - Adoption of uniform rules of the road. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-6-370, the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq., known as the uniform rules of the road, and the definitions contained in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of the town with like effect as if recited in this chapter. Sec. 46-53. - Parental responsibility. It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of a minor under the age of 16 years to permit, whether knowingly or through ineffective control or supervision, such minor to violate any provision of this Code or state law regarding the operation of vehicles. Sec. 46-54. - Temporary trac regulations. In cases where traffic upon the roads of the town may become congested upon occasions of parades, at theaters and other public assemblages where large numbers of vehicles are assembled, the sheriff may make temporary rules directing and regulating the traffic in these congested districts, and any person, who, after being warned of the temporary traffic regulations, shall violate them, shall be liable therefor as for other violations of this Code. Sec. 46-55. - Authorized emergency vehicles. The driver of any authorized emergency vehicle when responding to an emergency call or when in the pursuit of an actual or suspected violator of the law or when responding to, but not upon returning from a fire alarm, may 6/1/2019 Mount Airy, GA Code of Ordinances 246/316 (b) (c) (d) (1) (2) (3) (4) (a) (b) (1) (2) (c) (1) (2) (3) (4) exercise the privileges set forth in this section but subject to the conditions herein stated. The exemptions herein granted to an authorized emergency vehicle shall apply only when the driver of said vehicle while in motion sounds an audible signal by bell, siren or exhaust whistle as may be reasonably necessary, and when the vehicle is equipped with at least one lighted lamp displaying an emergency light visible under normal atmospheric conditions from a distance of 500 feet to the front of such vehicle, except that an authorized emergency vehicle operated as a police vehicle need not be equipped with or display a red light visible from in front of the vehicle. This section shall not be construed to relieve the driver of any authorized emergency vehicle from the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of all persons nor shall such provisions protect the driver from the consequences of his reckless disregard for the safety of others. Subject to the foregoing limitations, the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle may: Park or stand irrespective of the provisions of this article. Proceed past a traffic light or stop sign, but only slowing down as may be necessary for safe operation. Exceed the speed limits specified so long as he does not endanger life or property. Disregard regulations governing direction of movement or turning in specified directions so long as he does not endanger life or property. Sec. 46-56. - Improper operation of o-road vehicles. This section shall be considered as cumulative to any and all other laws, rules and regulations regarding the subject matter; however, if this section is in conflict with existing rules, regulations and resolutions, then where it is in conflict this section shall prevail and be considered governing. Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Off-road vehicle means any motorized vehicle designed for or capable of cross-country travel on or immediately over land, water, snow, ice, marsh, swampland or other natural terrain and not intended for use predominantly on public roads. The term "off-road vehicle" includes, but is not limited to, four-wheel-drive or low-pressure-tire vehicles, twowheel vehicles (including trail bikes and minibikes), amphibious machines, ground-effect or air-cushion vehicles, and any other means of transportation deriving power from any source other than muscle or wind. The term "off-road vehicle" does not include any motorboats; any military, fire or law enforcement vehicle; any vehicles used exclusively on airports; all farm machinery, farm tractors, and other self-propelled equipment for harvesting and transportation of forest products, for clearing land for planting, for utility service and maintenance, for earth moving, construction or mining; and self-propelled lawnmowers, snow blowers, garden or lawn tractors, or golf carts while such vehicles are being used exclusively for their designed purposes. As authorized by O.C.G.A. § 40-7-5, any person operating an off-road vehicle in the town under any of the following conditions shall be deemed to be in violation of this section: Without operative brakes, or without mufflers or other silencing equipment. In such a manner as to make, continue to make, or cause to be made any loud, unnecessary or unusual sound or noise which either endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace or safety of others in the town, and which is audible to a person of normal hearing ability more than 50 feet from the point of origin of such sound or noise. On any private property without the property owner or his agent being present or without being in possession of the expressed written permission of the property owner or his agent. On the right-of-way of any street, highway, avenue, lane, public throughway, etc., of the town. 6/1/2019 Mount Airy, GA Code of Ordinances 247/316 (5) (a) (b) (a) (b) (a) (b) On the roadway of any street or highway of the town without complying with all appropriate state laws and town Sec. 46-57. - Sale of vehicles on rights-of-way prohibited. It shall be unlawful to park or leave unattended on or within the right-of-way of any public road in the unincorporated areas of the town any used motor vehicle that is marked for sale or otherwise displayed for sale. A vehicle shall be considered to be displayed for sale when a reasonable person would perceive that the vehicle is for sale without having to inquire whether the vehicle is for sale. The law enforcement officials of the town are authorized and empowered to impound any vehicle found to be in violation of this section. The owner of such vehicle shall be responsible for all expenses and charges incurred in the towing and storage of the vehicle. Secs. 46-58—46-87. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - SPEED REGULATION FOOTNOTE(S): State Law reference— Maximum speed limits, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-181; power of local authorities to alter speed limits, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-183. Sec. 46-88. - Speed detection device authorized. The law enforcement officers of the town are authorized to use speed detection devices as permitted by O.C.G.A. § 40-14-2. (Res. of 5-11-1992) State law reference— Georgia Peace Officer Training Act, O.C.G.A. § 35-8-1 et seq.; authority for use or speed detection devices by local law enforcement officers, O.C.G.A. § 40-14-2; requirements that local government obtain state permit, O.C.G.A. § 40-14-2. Sec. 46-89. - Reduction of speed when speed hazards exist. No person shall drive a vehicle on a street or highway at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the existing conditions and with due regard for the actual and potential hazards that exist. In every event speed shall be so controlled as may be necessary to avoid colliding with any person, vehicle or other conveyance on or entering the street, road, highway or other avenues of travel, in compliance with legal requirements and the duty of all persons to use due care and caution. Where no speed hazards exist that require lower speed for compliance with subsection (a) of this section, the speed of any vehicle not less than the minimum limits or not in excess of the maximum limits or established as authorized herein, shall be lawful, but no speed equal to or less than the maximum limits specified in this section, or established as authorized by this section, shall be unlawful unless special hazards exist that might require lower speed for compliance with subsection (a) of this section. State law reference— Alteration of speed limits by local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-183. Sec. 46-90. - Speed restriction. The speed limit on all streets within the geographic limits of the town shall be 35 miles per hour, unless otherwise posted and except as provided in this section. The speed limit on Dicks Hill Parkway (Old U.S. Highway No 123) shall be 45 miles per hour. (36) 6/1/2019 Mount Airy, GA Code of Ordinances 248/316 (a) (b) (c) Secs. 46-91—46-108. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - ABANDONED VEHICLES FOOTNOTE(S): State Law reference— Junk dealers, O.C.G.A. § 43-22-1 et seq.; removal of junk vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-4. DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY Secs. 46-109—46-129. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PUBLIC PROPERTY Sec. 46-130. - Time limitation for vehicles parked on public street for continuous period. It shall be unlawful for the operator or owner of a vehicle to leave such vehicle parked in a public street for a continuous period of more than 24 hours. Any vehicle so parked for more than 24 hours shall be deemed abandoned. Sec. 46-131. - Vehicles without current license plates. It shall be unlawful for the operator or owner of a vehicle to leave such vehicle parked in a public street without said vehicle having affixed, or prominently displayed thereon, a current state license plate. Sec. 46-132. - Impounding vehicles authorized. Whenever a police officer or other officer acting under authority as direction of the town shall find any vehicle parked on any street or other place in violation of law or in violation of the ordinances of the town, or abandoned on any street or other public place, and such officer is unable to find the owner, operator, or other person responsible for the same in the immediate vicinity after making a reasonable search and investigation, it shall be his duty to take possession of such vehicle and tow it to a place of storage and keep it in possession of the town until claimed by the person entitled to its possession, if claimed within the time herein fixed; provided, however, that the person claiming the same shall pay all lawful costs as herein fixed. If deemed necessary by such officer he shall call upon a garageman or other person equipped for towing and storing such vehicles to remove said vehicle and store it. Whenever any officer shall find upon any street or at any other place within the town, any vehicle broken-down, wrecked, disabled, stalled, or in any condition or situation as to render the same likely to endanger life, limb or property, and the owner, operator or person in charge is unable or unwilling to take the proper steps, or unreasonably neglects to take the proper steps to remove the danger or to make the necessary correction with reasonable promptness, said officer shall cause the vehicle to be removed, impounded and kept in the manner specified in subsection (a) of this section, to be released upon compliance with the requirements of this article as to payment of costs and expenses. In all cases where the operator of a vehicle is found upon the public streets or public places of the town, ill, injured, intoxicated, or for any reason in a condition rendering him unfit to operate the vehicle, said officers may tow away and store such vehicle in the manner above provided, until released by compliance with the requirements of this article. (37) 6/1/2019 Mount Airy, GA Code of Ordinances 249/316 (a) (b) Sec. 46-133. - Redemption of impounded vehicles. The owner or person entitled to possession of a vehicle impounded pursuant to this article may redeem said vehicle at any time within 30 days of the date of impoundment by paying the actual costs of impounding, towing and storing said vehicle plus any penalty that may be assessed for violation of this article or any ordinance. Sec. 46-134. - Sale of unredeemed vehicles. In the event the owner or person entitled to possession of a vehicle impounded fails to redeem same as provided in this article, the town may proceed to effectuate its disposition by selling it after advertising said sale in the official town newspaper once. Said sale shall be by public auction for cash. Secs. 46-135—46-151. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - PRIVATE PROPERTY Sec. 46-152. - Authority for removal. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 36-60-4, derelict motor vehicles shall be removed from private property by the town and disposed of when requested by the landowner or when such motor vehicles are in such a condition that they constitute a health or safety hazard or an unsightly nuisance. For purposes of this division, the term "derelict motor vehicles" means motor vehicles or parts thereof that are inoperable due to lack of repairs or are unsafe to operate due to lack of repairs or damaged, or are discarded, dismantled, wrecked, scrapped or ruined. Sec. 46-153. - Removal when requested by private property owner. When removal of a derelict motor vehicle is requested by the landowner or when a derelict motor vehicle is observed upon private property, the police department shall affix a decal to said vehicle which shall give notice that if the vehicle is not removed within ten days, the town will cause the vehicle to be towed or removed from the property. Sec. 46-154. - Log of vehicles removed; disposal. The police department shall maintain a log identifying such vehicles. Any derelict motor vehicle which has been removed from private property as provided herein shall be disposed of as provided by law. Sec. 46-155. - Costs of removal; removal by private rms under contract. To minimize the cost to the town for the removal of derelict motor vehicles, the town shall contract with private individuals and firms whose operation includes the recycling of discarded, dismantled, wrecked, scrapped or ruined motor vehicles. The requesting landowner shall bear the cost of the removal of a derelict motor vehicle when such removal is requested by the landowner. Sec. 46-156. - Junkyards and automobile salvage yards excepted. Nothing contained within this section shall be deemed to apply to any motor vehicles which are located within the premises of any junkyard or automobile salvage yard complying with the laws of this state and town relating to the licensing and regulating of motor vehicles or junkyards. 6/1/2019 Mount Airy, GA Code of Ordinances 250/316

div.head: Chapter 48 - UTILITIES
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): State Law reference— Public utilities generally, O.C.G.A. § 46-1-1 et seq.; municipal home rule, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-1 et seq.; municipal utilities, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-5; Georgia Water Quality Control Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-20 et seq.; water resources, O.C.G.A. § 12- 5-1 et seq.; public water systems, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-170 et seq.; water supply, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-470; sewage and waste disposal, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-29 et seq.; refusal by city or county to supply water because of indebtedness of prior owner, occupant, or lessee prohibited and limited liens for unpaid utility charges, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-17. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Sec. 48-1. - Damage to public utility property prohibited. No unauthorized person shall maliciously, willfully, or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface, or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which is a part of the municipal water, garbage collection, or fire protection service. Any person violating this provision shall be subject to immediate arrest under charge of disorderly conduct or malicious mischief. Sec. 48-2. - Right of entry for inspection, repair, and maintenance. Duly authorized agents of the town shall have access at all hours to the premises of the consumer for the purpose of installing or removing town property, inspecting piping, reading and testing meters, observation, measurement, sampling, testing, or for any other purpose in connection with the water service. Sec. 48-3. - Promulgation of policies, rules, regulations and requirements. The mayor and council of the town shall have the authority, pursuant to this section, to promulgate policies, regulations and written provisions concerning the water service system of the town. Any such written policies, regulations or requirements promulgated pursuant to this section shall be complied with by all customers and users of this service. Violations of any regulations shall result in penalties, discontinuances of service or other action as might be required pursuant to the provisions of this chapter and any and all other applicable federal, state or local provisions governing and regulating the water service system. Sec. 48-4. - Grant of easement required for extension of water system. Extensions to the system shall be made only when the consumer shall grant or convey, or shall cause to be granted or conveyed, to the town a permanent easement of right-of-way across any property traversed by the water lines. Sec. 48-5. - Notice of change of occupancy; responsibility for services. Not less than three days notice must be given, in person or in writing, at the town hall to discontinue water service or to change occupancy. The outgoing party shall be responsible for all water consumed up to the time of departure or the time specified for departure, whichever period is longer. The new occupant shall apply for water service within 48 hours after occupying the premises and failure to do so will make him liable for paying for the water consumed since the last meter reading. Sec. 48-6. - Tap fees. Upon the application for a new water service connection by any customer, the tap fees specified in the town fee schedule shall be paid to the town clerk as a nonrefundable tapping charge. (38) 6/1/2019 Mount Airy, GA Code of Ordinances 251/316 Secs. 48-7—48-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - WATER Sec. 48-31. - Application for service. Application for the use of water shall be made to the town clerk by the owner or agent of the property to be benefited, designating the location of the property and stating the purposes for which the water may be required. Sec. 48-32. - Town to install distribution line; connection fee. The town shall run a service line from its distribution line to the property line where the distribution line exists or is to be constructed, and runs immediately adjacent and parallel to the property to be served. No service charge, other than the connection fee provided in the town fee schedule, will be made for a five-eighths-inch meter by three-fourths-inch meter. A proportionately greater charge than the connection fee above will be made for a meter of larger dimensions. Sec. 48-33. - Ownership of water service lines. The town shall own and maintain the water line from the main to the curb box. The property owner shall own and maintain the service line from the curb box to the premises served. Sec. 48-34. - Work on service lines to be performed by licensed plumber. All work on water lines owned by the property owner shall be performed by a licensed plumber. Sec. 48-35. - Extension of distribution lines. The town may make connections to service other properties not adjacent to its lines upon payment of reasonable costs for the extensions of its distribution lines as may be required to render such service. Sec. 48-36. - Refusal of service for potential cross connections. The town reserves the right to refuse service unless the consumer's lines or pipings are installed in such a manner as to prevent cross connections or backflow. Sec. 48-37. - Notication of disruptions in service. Under normal conditions, the consumer will be notified of any anticipated interruptions of service by the town. Sec. 48-38. - Use of town water restricted. Water furnished by the town shall be used for consumption by the consumer, members of his household and employees only. The consumer shall not sell water to any other person or permit any other person to use said water. Water shall not be used for irrigation, fire protection, nor other purposes, except when water is available in sufficient quantity without interfering with the regular domestic consumption in the area served. Disregard for this rule shall be sufficient cause for refusal or discontinuance of service. Sec. 48-39. - Cuto valve to be installed and maintained by consumer. 6/1/2019 Mount Airy, GA Code of Ordinances 252/316 (a) (b) (c) (d) The consumer shall furnish and maintain a private cutoff valve on the consumer's side of the water meter. Sec. 48-40. - Piping to be installed and maintained by consumer. The consumer's piping and apparatus shall be installed and maintained by the consumer at the consumer's expense, in a safe and efficient manner, and in accordance with the sanitary regulations of the state health department. Sec. 48-41. - Private wells; proof of nonconnection required. In order to be received as a consumer and entitled to receive water from the town's water system, all applicants must offer proof that any private wells located on their property are not physically connected to the lines of the town's water system, and all applicants, by becoming consumers of the town covenant and agree that so long as they continue to be consumers of the town, will not permit the connection of any private wells on their property to the town's water system. Sec. 48-42. - Water meters required; installation; reading. All premises using the town water supply shall be equipped with an adequate water meter furnished by the town at the expense of the property owner. All meters shall be installed on the edge of public rights-of-way, or where the water superintendent may determine. All meters shall be maintained by the town. The town may install its meter at or near the property line or, at the town's option, on the consumer's property within three feet of the property line. Where a meter or meter box is placed on the premises of a consumer, a suitable place shall be provided by the consumer therefor, unobstructed and accessible at all times to the meter reader. Each water meter shall supply service to an individual consumer, business or commercial customer. Water meters shall not supply water to more than one residential, commercial or industrial customer. Sec. 48-43. - Permission required for work performed by private plumber. No plumber or other person shall make attachments to any pipe or water fixture, nor to any pipe where the water has been turned off unless permission has been granted by the water works authorities; nor shall any plumber or other person alter or extend any water pipes or attachments to conduct any water into any adjoining premises or any additional hydrants, stable, water closet, urinal, washbasin, cistern or fountain or for any purpose whatsoever without obtaining permission from the water works authorities, and in every instance the plumber, after having tested his work must turn the water off and make returns to the water works office within 48 hours after completing the work. Sec. 48-44. - Shuto of water at curb stop restricted. Water shall not be turned on or off under any circumstances by the curb stop to any premises for any purpose, but by the authority or superintendent of the water works, except only by the plumber for testing his work, who must turn the water off immediately thereafter, and not leave same on unless by permission. Secs. 48-45—48-61. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - SEWER DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 6/1/2019 Mount Airy, GA Code of Ordinances 253/316 (a) (b) (c) Secs. 48-62—48-80. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PRIVATE SEWAGE DISPOSAL Sec. 48-81. - Applicability of state and county regulations. The type, capacities, location and layout of a private sewage disposal system shall comply with all county and state recommendations and regulations. Sec. 48-82. - County permit required. No septic tank may be constructed or installed in the town unless the owner of the property on which it is to be situated shall obtain a county septic tank permit. Secs. 48-83—48-107. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - CHARGES, BILLING, AND COLLECTIONS Sec. 48-108. - Consumer of water or garbage services required to pay fee for all town services. The town provides water, garbage collection, and fire protection services at the rates specified in the town fee schedule. Any person subscribing to less than all town services shall nevertheless be required to pay the applicable fee for all town services, regardless of whether the consumer actually uses the service. Sec. 48-109. - Owner of multiple properties responsible for payment of all accounts; disconnection of services. In the event a single property owner subscribes to town utility services for more than one property, the delinquency in payment of one account shall be grounds for disconnection of services to all properties of the same owner, regardless of delinquencies, until such time as all of that owner's accounts are paid in full, including late fees, penalties, disconnection charges, and reconnection charges. Sec. 48-110. - Meter readings. The water superintendent shall cause every water meter in the town to be read at such times as are necessary for monthly utility billing. Sec. 48-111. - Disputed billings; rechecks. If the consumer believes his bill to be in error, he shall present his claim, in person, at the town hall, before the bill becomes delinquent. Such claim, if made after the bill has become delinquent, shall not be effective in preventing discontinuance of service as heretofore provided. The consumer may pay such bill under protest and said payment shall not prejudice his claim. The town will make a special water meter reading at the request of a consumer for a fee as set forth in the town fee schedule; provided, however, that if such special reading discloses that the meter was overread, no charge will be made. For requests for rechecks when usage is less than 30 percent above the previous six months average or in the event of multiple recheck in the same monthly billing cycle, a recheck service charge shall be assessed. In the event any 6/1/2019 Mount Airy, GA Code of Ordinances 254/316 (d) (a) (b) (c) (1) (2) (3) (a) (b) (1) (2) (3) (4) (5) (6) (7) recheck reveals a meter reading error and/or a defective meter, no service charge shall be assessed. Water meters will be tested at the request of the consumer upon payment to the town of the actual costs of making the test; provided, however, that if the meter is found to overregister beyond three percent of the correct volume, no charge will be made. Sec. 48-112. - Estimated billing upon meter damage or failure. If the seal of a meter is broken by other than the town's representative or if the meter fails to register correctly or is stopped for any cause, the consumer shall pay an amount estimated from the record of his previous bills and/or from other proper data. Sec. 48-113. - Billing; delinquencies and penalties. Bills to customers for water service shall be mailed out on such days of each month as may be determined as desirable by the town. Bills shall be paid at the town hall. Failure to receive bills or notices shall not prevent such bills from becoming delinquent nor relieve the consumer from payment of same. The failure of water users to timely pay charges duly imposed shall result in the automatic imposition of the following penalties: Nonpayment within 20 days from the due date will be subject to a penalty of ten percent of the delinquent account. Nonpayment within 40 days from the date due will result in the water being shut off from the water user's property. Nonpayment for 60 days after original due date will allow the town, in addition to all other rights and remedies, to terminate service to the property. Sec. 48-114. - Disconnection for nonpayment; reconnection fees. Water service may be discontinued for delinquency in the payment of sums due for water service, garbage collection service, or fire protection services. Service disconnected for nonpayment of bills will be restored only after bills are paid in full, such security deposit or additional security deposit as may be required by the mayor and council is made, and a reconnection fee as provided in the town fee schedule is paid for each meter reconnected. Upon discontinuance of service for nonpayment of bills, in the event reconnection is not requested within a reasonable time, the security deposit will be applied by the town toward settlement of the account. Any balance will be refunded to the consumer; however, if the security deposit is insufficient to cover the bill, the town may proceed to collect the balance in the usual way provided by law for collection of debts. Sec. 48-115. - Disconnection of service for reasons other than nonpayment. The town reserves a right to discontinue its service without notice for the following additional reasons: To prevent fraud or abuse; Consumer's willful disregard of the town's rules; Emergency repairs; Insufficiency of water supply due to circumstances beyond the town's control; Legal processes; Direction of public authorities; Strike, riot, fire, flood, unavoidable accident. 6/1/2019 Mount Airy, GA Code of Ordinances 255/316 (a) (b) (a) (b) Sec. 48-116. - Deposits and service charges. The deposit and service charges for water, garbage, and fire protection service shall be as set forth in the town fee schedule. Sec. 48-117. - Special rates for extraordinary service requirements. Extraordinary circumstances, such as multiple dwelling units, industrial users, and fire protection, shall be governed by special contract agreements made by the mayor and town council. Sec. 48-118. - Minimum service rates; use limitations; no free water provided. The minimum charge, as provided in the town fee schedule, shall be made for such connection subscribed for. Water furnished for a given lot shall be used on that lot only and, except for fire protection, the town shall not under any condition furnish water free of charge to anyone. Sec. 48-119. - Temporary service reduction rates. Any owner or occupant of a single-family dwelling in the town may apply for a temporary service reduction rate for periods during which the property will be vacant for 60 days or more. Applications shall be submitted to the county clerk and approved by the mayor upon such conditions as he deems appropriate or necessary. If the application is approved, the owner or occupant shall, during the vacancy of the property, be billed the minimum rate for water usage and shall not be billed for garbage service during the approved period; provided, however, that should the owner, the occupant, or any other person use more than the minimum amount of water or use any garbage collection services, the service reduction rates shall be immediately rescinded and all town utility service charges shall be restored for the month in which the use occurs and for all subsequent months, unless and until a new temporary service reduction request is approved. Sec. 48-120. - Minimum and additional service deposits. The deposit amounts set forth in the town fee schedule represent the minimum deposit required for the classes of water service customers within the municipal service area. In addition to that minimum, the town may, in its discretion, charge an additional deposit which shall not exceed 2½ times the customers' estimated average monthly bill during any consecutive 12- month period. Sec. 48-121. - Separate deposits required for each meter; deposit not transferable from meter to meter. A separate water service deposit shall be required for each meter and such deposits shall be considered nontransferable. Sec. 48-122. - Refund of deposit upon discontinuance of service; deposit transferable to new service location. All deposits will be applied against the customer's final bill when such final bill is presented by the customer for payment or before a refund is made. Customers who have deposits with the town may transfer the deposit to a new service location, subject to any required minimum increase in the event the amount on deposit is a preexisting amount prior to the enactment of this section or the deposit, in the town's discretion, is not sufficient to ensure payment to the town for the services provided. Refunds will be made by applying the deposit to the customer's account. In the event of final billing for discontinued accounts in which the deposit exceeds the amount due, refunds shall be sent by certified mail or may be claimed in person at the town clerk's office. Any unclaimed deposits shall inure to, and be forfeited to the town; unless claimed within 90 days of final payment to the municipality. There shall not be deposit refunds in amounts less than $2.50. 6/1/2019 Mount Airy, GA Code of Ordinances 256/316 (a) (b) (a) Sec. 48-123. - Refund of deposit when service is not discontinued. Deposits may, in the town's discretion, be refunded after 24 consecutive months of service, provided that the customer has no unsatisfactory credit problems. Refunds will be made by applying the deposit to the customer's account; provided that commercial and industrial customers are not eligible for deposit refunds. In the event of final billing for discontinued accounts in which the deposit exceeds the amount due, refunds shall be sent by certified mail or may be claimed in person at the town clerk's office. Any unclaimed deposits shall inure to, and be forfeited to the town; unless claimed within 90 days of final payment to the municipality. There shall not be deposit refunds in amounts less than $2.50.

div.head: Chapter 50 - VEGETATION
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): State Law reference— Plant disease, pest control and pesticides, O.C.G.A. § 2-7-1 et seq.; forest resources and other plant life, O.C.G.A. § 12-6-1 et seq.; timber harvesting and removal requirements, O.C.G.A. § 12-6-23 et seq. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Sec. 50-1. - Denitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Weed means any brush, grass, vegetation, or any plant that is not regularly cut or cultivated. The term "weed" shall not include plants maintained in a garden or for agricultural purposes. A plant shall be deemed to be regularly cultivated within the meaning of this chapter if it is routinely cared for by any person or to foster, encourage, or promote its growth. Secs. 50-2—50-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - WEEDS Sec. 50-21. - Applicability. This article applies to owners and occupants of all residential and commercial structures and to any person who owns a vacant, developed or undeveloped property. Sec. 50-22. - Excessive, uncontrolled growth; exception. The excessive, unmaintained, and uncontrolled growth of any weeds within 50 feet of the property line of a habitable dwelling or commercial building on any lot or within 50 feet of a town street or highway within the corporate limits of the town is objectionable, unsightly, and unsanitary and shall constitute a nuisance. It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any such property as defined in this Code to permit such growth to occur. This section shall not be applicable to flower gardens, undeveloped property, or plots used for agricultural purposes or the regular cultivation of any plant or other vegetation, or undeveloped property, or weeds and vegetation. Sec. 50-23. - Poison ivy, poison sumac. Nuisance declared. Toxicodendron or toxicodendron vernix, commonly known as poison ivy and poison sumac, are hereby declared to be nuisances per se, the existence and growing of which constitutes a menace to the health of (39) 6/1/2019 Mount Airy, GA Code of Ordinances 257/316 (b) (c) (1) (2) (3) (4) (5) the citizens of the town and is dangerous to all persons coming in contact therewith. Duty of owner, occupant. It shall be the duty of every person who owns or who is in possession of a lot upon which such plants grow to take such action as will effectively kill and destroy such poisonous plants, and it shall be unlawful for such person to fail to do so. Duty, authority of town inspector. The inspector of the town is hereby authorized and directed to destroy all poison ivy or poison sumac plants growing upon the street, sidewalks or other property belonging to the town. The inspector and any employee of the town are likewise authorized to enter upon private property for the purpose of destroying those plants when it is necessary to protect the public, following the procedures of this article. Sec. 50-24. - Public nuisance. Violation of this article is deemed as a public nuisance, which may be abated as provided by state law. Secs. 50-25—50-51. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - TREES AND SHRUBS Sec. 50-52. - Regulations. No person shall, without the consent of the owner in the case of a tree or shrub on private property or without permission from the town in the case of a tree or shrub on town property, do any of the following acts: Climb, bark, break, peel, cut, deface, injure or destroy the whole or any part of any tree, sapling, or shrubs now growing or which may hereafter be planted by any person or by the town in any street or public place of the town, nor may any such tree be removed or cut down unless by permission of the town. Secure, fasten or run any rope, wire, sign, or other device or material to, around or through a tree or shrub. Permit any fire to burn where it will injure any tree or shrub. Permit any toxic chemical, gas, smoke, brine, oil or other injurious substance to seep, drain, or be emptied upon any tree or shrub. Place any stone, concrete, brick or any other impervious material in such a manner as to obstruct the free access of air and water to the roots of the tree or shrub. Sec. 50-53. - Dead or diseased trees. Any dead or diseased tree or part of a tree is a nuisance per se when, by reason of such condition, natural forces may, more readily than if such tree or part thereof were live or not diseased, cause the tree or any part thereof to fall onto public ways, public sidewalks or public property, or onto private property, off the property of the owner of the tree and thereby imperil life, property or impede traffic. Upon receiving a written opinion from a qualified tree service that any tree or part thereof is a nuisance per se, the inspector shall commence abatement proceedings pursuant to the procedure provided in chapter 30. Sec. 50-54. - Approval of council. The town inspector shall report to the town council on each application to remove trees or shrubs. Each report shall include a recommendation of approval or disapproval of the application. The town council shall then approve or disapprove such application in writing.

div.head: Chapter 52 - ZONING
div.p: 6/1/2019 Mount Airy, GA Code of Ordinances 258/316 FOOTNOTE(S): State Law reference— Downtown development authorities, O.C.G.A. § 36-42-1 et seq.; municipal business improvement districts, O.C.G.A. § 36-43-1 et seq.; redevelopment authority of municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 36-44-1; city and county development authorities, O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1 et seq.; county and municipal urban development, O.C.G.A. § 36-61-1 et seq.; city and county zoning procedures, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-1 et seq.; local zoning proposal review procedures, O.C.G.A. § 36-67-1 et seq.; conflicts of interest in zoning actions, O.C.G.A. § 36-67A-1 et seq.; coordinated and comprehensive planning and service delivery by counties and municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 36-70-1 et seq. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Sec. 52-1. - Denitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Accessory building or use means a building or use which is subordinate to and serves a principal building or principal use; is subordinate in area, extent, or purpose to the principal building or use served; contributes to the comfort, convenience or necessity of occupants of the principal building or principal use; and is located on the same lot as the principal building or principal use. Agriculture means the cultivation or growth of a field or horticultural crop, including dairying, livestock and poultry raising, farm forestry, and other similar enterprises or uses. Airport means any area of land, water or mechanical structure which is used for the landing and takeoff of aircraft, including any appurtenant structures and areas which are used or intended to be used for airport buildings, other airport facilities, rights-of way easements. Alley means a private or public thoroughfare which affords only a secondary means of access to a building or abutting property and is not intended for general traffic circulation. Alteration means any change in the supporting members of a building, any modification or change in construction, any addition which increases the area or height, any change in use from that of one district classification to another, or movement of a building from one location to another. Apartment house means a multifamily dwelling located on a parcel of land under a single ownership, designed for use by three or more housekeeping units, living independently of each other, and doing their own cooking on the premises. Basement means that portion of a building located wholly or partly underground but having less than one-half of its height above the grade. Bed and breakfast inn means a dwelling unit, or portion thereof, where shortterm lodging rooms, with or without meals, are provided for compensation, and where the operator of the inn resides on the premises. Board of zoning appeals means the body established by these regulations composed of or appointed by the town council which has original jurisdiction to take action on appeals, variances, and other determinations as herein established. Boardinghouse means a building, where for compensation, both lodging and meals are provided for persons, provided that a single-family dwelling shall not be deemed to be boarding with the owner or tenant occupying the dwelling by a person related by blood or marriage. (40) 6/1/2019 Mount Airy, GA Code of Ordinances 259/316 Buffer means a landscaped open space and/or screen located between incompatible land uses for the purpose of visibly separating uses through distance and to shield or block noise, light, glare, or visual or other nuisances; that portion of a given lot, not covered by buildings, pavement, parking access and service areas, established for the purpose of screening and separating properties with incompatible land uses, the width of which is measured from the common property line and extending the developed portion of the common property line. A buffer consists of trees, shrubs and other natural vegetation undisturbed by grading or site development and replanted where sparsely vegetated or where disturbed for approved access and utility crossings. Buildable area means the portion of a lot remaining after required yards, buffers and building setbacks have been provided, where construction of principal buildings is permitted. Building means any structure, either temporary or permanent, above or below ground, having a roof or other covering, and designed, built, or used as a shelter or enclosure for persons animals, or property of any kind, including tents, awnings, or vehicles used for purposes of a building. Building addition means any walled and roofed expansion to the perimeter of a building in which the addition is connected by a common loadbearing wall other than a firewall. Any walled and roofed addition which is connected by a firewall or is separated by independent perimeter loadbearing walls are new construction. Building official means the town clerk or an authorized representative. Building, principal, means a building or structure in which is conducted the main use of the property on which the building or structure is located. In any residential district, any structure containing a dwelling unit shall be defined to be the principal building on the lot on which said structure is located. ARTICLE II. - ESTABLISHMENT OF DISTRICTS Sec. 52-21. - Use districts. For the purpose of this chapter, the town is hereby divided into use districts as set out in this section: R-1, single-family residential district; R-2, multiple-family residential district; B-1, neighborhood business district; I, industrial district. (Ord. of 12-1-2005, § 401) Sec. 52-22. - Ocial zoning map. The location and boundaries of the above-listed districts are hereby established as shown on a map entitled the Official Zoning Map of the Town of Mount Airy, Georgia. Said map, together with all explanatory matter thereon, is hereby adopted by reference and declared to be a part of this chapter. The official zoning map shall be identified by the signature of the mayor, attested by the town clerk, and bear the seal of the town or that of a notary public under the following words: "This is to certify that this is an official zoning map referred to in article II of the Zoning Ordinance, Town of Mount Airy, Georgia," together with the date of the adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived. If in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and the applicable laws of the state, changes are made in boundaries or other matter portrayed on the official zoning map, such changes shall be entered on the official zoning map promptly after the amendment has been approved by the town council, with appropriate entry or indication of such amendment on the official zoning map. No amendment to this chapter which involves matter portrayed on the official zoning map shall become effective until after such change and entry has been made on said map. No changes of any nature shall be made in the official zoning map or matter shown thereon, except in conformity 6/1/2019 Mount Airy, GA Code of Ordinances 268/316 (e) (a) (b) (a) (b) (c) (d) (e) with the procedures set forth in this chapter. Any unauthorized change of whatever kind by any person shall be considered a violation of this chapter. Regardless of the existence of purported copies of the official zoning map which may from time to time be made or published the official zoning map shall be located in the office of the town clerk, and shall be the final authority as to the current zoning status of land and water areas, buildings, and other structures in the town. (Ord. of 12-1-2005, § 402) Sec. 52-23. - Replacement of ocial zoning map. In the event that the official zoning map becomes damaged, destroyed, lost or difficult to interpret because of the nature or number of changes and additions, the town council may adopt a new official zoning map which shall supersede the prior official zoning map. The new official zoning map may correct drafting or other errors or omissions in the prior official zoning map, but no such correction shall have the effect of amending the original official zoning map or any subsequent amendment thereof. The new official zoning map shall be identified by the signature of the mayor, attested by the town clerk, and bear the seal of the town or a notary public under the following words: "This is to certify that this official zoning map supersedes and replaces the official zoning map adopted (date of adoption of map being replaced) as part of the zoning ordinance of the Town of Mount Airy, Georgia." Unless the prior official zoning map has been lost, or has been totally destroyed, the prior map or any significant parts thereof that remain, shall be preserved, together with all available records pertaining to its adoption or amendment. (Ord. of 12-1-2005, § 403) Sec. 52-24. - Interpretation of district boundaries. Where boundaries are indicated as approximately following the centerline of streets or highways, street right-of-way lines or railroad right-of-way lines or such lines extended, such centerline, street right-of-way lines, or railroad rightof-way lines shall be construed to be such boundaries. Where boundaries are indicated as approximately following the corporate limit line of a city or town, such corporate limit line shall be construed to be such boundaries. Where boundaries are indicated as approximately following property lines or such lines extended, as indicated by boundary survey, deed or legal description maintained in the official file or said zoning adoption or amendment, if available, shall be construed to be such boundaries. Where boundaries are indicated as approximately following the centerline shall be construed to be such boundaries. In the case where the exact location of a boundary cannot be determined by the foregoing methods, the board of zoning appeals shall, upon application, determine the location of the boundary. (Ord. of 12-1-2005, § 404) Sec. 52-25. - Boundary line divides a lot of single ownership. Where a boundary line as appearing on the official zoning map divides a lot in single ownership at the time of the enactment of these regulations, the requirements for the district in which the greater portion of the lot lie may be extended to the balance of the lot without recourse to the amendment procedure, provided that this provision shall not apply to a double frontage lot. In the case of a double frontage lot, the restrictions of the district applying to the adjoining lots which front on the same street as the lot frontage in question shall apply. (Ord. of 12-1-2005, § 406) Secs. 52-27—52-55. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - NONCONFORMING LOTS, BUILDINGS AND USES Sec. 52-56. - Purpose and intent. Within the districts established by this chapter, there exist certain incompatible lots, buildings, structures, signs and uses of land which were lawful before these regulations were adopted but which would be prohibited, regulated or restricted under the terms of these regulations or future amendments. It is the intention of this article to permit these nonconformities to continue, but not to encourage them. Nonconformities shall not be enlarged upon, expanded or extended, nor be used as grounds for variances or for adding other structures or uses prohibited elsewhere in the same district. (Ord. of 12-1-2005, § 501) Sec. 52-57. - Nonconforming lots of record. In any district, notwithstanding limitations imposed by other provisions of these regulations, a single-family dwelling and customary accessory buildings or any other permitted use may be erected on any single lot of record existing at the effective date of adoption or amendment of these regulations, even though such lot fails to meet the requirements for area or width, or both, applicable to the particular district involved, provided that yard dimensions and other requirements of the lot shall conform to the regulations for the district in which the lot is located. (Ord. of 12-1-2005, § 502) Sec. 52-58. - Continuance of nonconforming use. The lawful use of any building, structure, sign or land existing at the time of enactment of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived may be continued, subject to the limitations of section 52-59, even though such use does not conform with the provisions of these regulations, except that the use of a principal building, structure or land containing a nonconforming use shall not be: Changed to another nonconforming use; Reestablished after discontinuance or abandonment for six months; Expanded, enlarged or extended, unless such use is changed to a use permitted in the district in which such use if located; rebuilt, altered or repaired after damage exceeding 50 percent of its replacement cost at the time of destruction as determined by the building official and provided such rebuilding, alteration or repair is completed with one year of such damage; Moved in whole or in part to any other portion of the lot occupied by such use, except in conformity with these regulations. (Ord. of 12-1-2005, § 503) Sec. 52-59. - Expansion of nonconforming buildings. A nonconforming building which contains a conforming use may be expanded, enlarged or extended, provided that any such additions meet the applicable building setbacks and all other regulations for the district in which they are located.
